calEvent.description:
Soak up the atmosphere of our historic bar room and lovely outdoor patio and enjoy the Inn as it might have been in the 1840s, with a live band! 

Visitors can sit in the historic bar room, buy a drink at the bar and enjoy a meat or veggie hand pie in the historic kitchen. 

Montgomery's Inn is one of 10 Toronto History Museums which explore where Toronto's many pasts, presents and futures meet. The museum highlights the historical role played by the inn as a tavern, farm, local gathering place and community hub in the development and history of Etobicoke. 

Please call 416-394-8113 for specific accessibility questions

This event is part of Toronto's Table, a new culinary program at Toronto History Museums.

calEvent.description:
Come sing, laugh, and make music on one of the world’s easiest instruments to play, the humble ukulele. On the first Thursday of every month, Montgomery's Inn is home to a ukulele night, hosted by instructor Dr. Chris Wilson, a professional musician with a passion for helping people make music in their own lives through his practice of ‘Live and Learn Music’. 

Take part in a free chord workshop, followed by a paid, two hour session with popular tunes and music by Canadian performers. 

Bring your own ukulele, or borrow a spare, but beware, as they go fast! 

Montgomery's Inn is one of 10 Toronto History Museums which explore where Toronto's many pasts, presents and futures meet.

calEvent.description:
Through beadwork, textiles, photography, video and sculpture, Montreal-based artist Nadia Myre draws attention to the power and histories of Indigenous textile practices that she situates in a colonial context. "Balancing Acts" is a survey of artwork made over the last ten years – some on view in this exhibition for the first time. 

Nadia Myre is a Montreal-based interdisciplinary artist of mixed Algonquin and French Canadian heritage. A member of the Kitigan Zibi Anishnabeg First Nation, her work explores the politics of belonging by positioning her practice within a framework of resistance and resilience.

"Nadia Myre: Balancing Acts" is a Primary Exhibition of the 2019 Scotiabank Contact Photography Festival
calEvent.otherCostInfo: Family (5 individuals; max. 2 adults) - $30.00

calEvent.description: Welcome back to the future! Science fiction tries to predict the effects of change on future societies and asks the question "What if?" The answers that science fiction writers and illustrators come up with are often creative, inspiring, sometimes alarming, and range from the plausible to the far-fetched.  Retro Futures invites you on a nostalgic journey to futures-that-might-have- been. Using the 50th anniversary of NASA's first successful lunar landing in 1969 as its inspiration, Retro Futures features rare books, magazines, artwork and ephemera from the Toronto Public Library's Merril Collection of Science Fiction, Speculation and Fantasy. Warp speed ahead!

calEvent.description:
The exhibition, An Index, exposes work by the first cohort of residency artists who entered Akin’s Studio Program in September 2018. While the participating artists’ practices range widely in terms of conceptual approach, style and media; they have also been influenced to some degree by the experience of sharing and conversing within Akin’s open-plan studio structure for the last nine months.

MOCA has invited curators Marsya Maharani and Marjan Verstappen, associated with the Younger than Beyonce Gallery, to work with the 24 participating artists. The curators’ proposal, An Index, speaks to process and production, to the varied artistic approaches found within one context and the relationships built through this programme.

calEvent.description:
Join Umair Jaffar as he explores the changing face of qawwali, a devotional genre of music thought to have originated in Sufi shrines

 Today, qawwali is increasingly being performed outside of its sacred milieu — at weddings, corporate events, and social gatherings. How does this align with its sacred origins? Is the soul of qawwali fading?

Jaffar delves into to these questions and unravels the various interpretations of qawwali music in contemporary Pakistan.

calEvent.description:
Join the Toronto Zoo in celebrating Global Tiger Weekend! Our celebration not only focuses on the plight tigers are facing in the wild, but aims to build appreciation for this beautiful carnivore. 

Get to know our Sumatran tiger’s Hari and Kemala and enjoy activities such as: touch tables, educational games, extra enrichment opportunities, and a chance to meet our tiger keepers. 

Sumatran Tigers are critically endangered in the wild. Tiger’s only live in 7% of their historic range, and in the last 100 years we have lost 97% of the global wild tiger population. With less than 400 Sumatran Tigers left in the wild we need your help to ensure a rich diversity of wildlife for future generations.
calEvent.otherCostInfo: Event is free with paid admission.

This 11-day festival features both free and ticketed programming that will uncover the hidden potential and concealed aspects of the human existence through experiential theatre, immersive art, music, food and literature.

calEvent.description:
Craft beer may be all the rage today in Toronto, but the city has a brewing tradition that began over two centuries ago. Through artifacts, artworks, archival images and videos, you can explore this rich legacy in the Market Gallery's new exhibition.  The story begins with tiny breweries established in the early 1800s, then covers the scaling-up of the industry in Victorian times, the impact of Prohibition, the rise of Canada's macrobrewers in the first half of the 20th century, and ends with a look at the microbrewery movement since 1985 and contemporary craft-beer culture.

The Market Gallery is one of 10 Toronto History Museums which explore where Toronto's many pasts, presents and futures meet. It encloses all that remains of Toronto’s original 19th-century Front Street City Hall council chamber, operating from 1845-1899. The historic site presents a variety of changing exhibits related to the art, culture and history of Toronto.
calEvent.otherCostInfo:
5 and under – free.
50% off admission each Friday.

calEvent.description:
Welcome to the 28th season of our lunchtime concert series at the Church of the Holy Trinity! Music Mondays has served as a launching pad for emerging talent since its inception in 1992, featuring an eclectic mix of everything from classical solo and chamber music to jazz, fusion and world music. Our goal is to provide the highest possible musical experience to a pay-what-you-can downtown Toronto audience.

Named to the CBC's '30 hot Canadian classical musicians under 30, 2018 edition', Canadian pianist Kevin Ahfat is “poised to become one of the young heirs of the classical piano realm,” (Vanguard Seattle). His Music Mondays performance will be recorded for broadcast by CBC Radio Two, In Concert. “From México to Germany, from Argentina to the Russian Empire, I'll take the audience on a wild ride through space & time, taking the listener from the nostalgic and tender memories of childhood, to the terror of the gruesome witch Baba-Yaga, to festive salsa dancing in Cuba.” – Kevin Ahfat

Join renowned Toronto musicians Wendy Zhou (Chinese pipa), Padideh Ahrarnejad (Persian tar) and Ali Massoudi (percussion) for a tantalizing day of musical fusion. Featuring works from both traditional and contemporary repertoire, these artists will take you on a journey through the East via the silk road. Brian Katz (guitar, piano, vocals), famed jazz and Jewish music artist and Jonno Lightstone, acclaimed klezmer clarinettist/flautist combine their talents to explore some rarely performed klezmer repertoire as well as the beloved pulsating dance music of this exciting genre. Welcome to the 28th season of our lunchtime concert series at the Church of the Holy Trinity! Music Mondays has served as a launching pad for emerging talent since its inception in 1992, featuring an eclectic mix of everything from classical solo and chamber music to jazz, fusion and world music. 

The Ageless Beauty of Maturity

Vancouver native Albert Seo studies at the Curtis Institute with Carter Brey, principal cello of the New York Philharmonic, and Peter Wiley, former cellist of the Guarneri Quartet.  He will be joined by Toronto-based, Filipino-American pianist Tristan Savella, a graduate of Eastman School of Music, and currently a DMA candidate at U of T. Their program "Ageless Beauty of Maturity" will feature works composed late in composers' lives: Nikolai Korndorf's Triptych for Cello and Piano, Brahms' Cello Sonata No.2 in F Major Op. 99 and Beethoven's Sonata for Cello and Piano No. 4 in C major, Op. 102.

calEvent.description: To mark the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 lunar landing The Moon: A Voyage Through Time explores our enduring fascination with this enchanting orb in the sky and looks at the role it has played in faith, science, and the arts across the Muslim world and beyond. This major new exhibition showcases ancient artifacts, important miniature paintings, scientific instruments, Islamic manuscripts, and contemporary art. Together with interactive devices, displays, and installations The Moon: A Voyage Through Time invites us to observe and imagine the moon in new ways.

calEvent.description:
Welcome to the 28th season of our lunchtime concert series at the Church of the Holy Trinity! Music Mondays has served as a launching pad for emerging talent since its inception in 1992, featuring an eclectic mix of everything from classical solo and chamber music to jazz, fusion and world music. Our goal is to provide the highest possible musical experience to a pay-what-you-can downtown Toronto audience.

War of the Foxes – Praised by Toronto Weekly for his “charming sensitivity and whole-hearted intellect,” Stanford Cheung has established himself as a musician of refined style. His program "War of the Foxes" coins its title from the poet Richard Siken. The collage of pieces presented seek to stipple a storyline of narrative soundscapes from Kodaly’s jaunting Marosszéker Tänze to Rachmaninoff's stark Prelude in B minor, Op. 32, No. 10.

Penrose Trio was formed in 2016 by three friends, pianist Emily Rho, violinist Aaron Schwebel, and cellist Britton Riley. Aaron is the Associate Concertmaster of the Canadian Opera Company and Concertmaster of the National Ballet Orchestra, Britton is a member of the Toronto Symphony Orchestra and Artistic Director of Chamber Music @ New Park, and Emily is a co-director of Pocket Concerts and a faculty member at The Royal Conservatory of Music. calEvent.description:
This summer program is designed for all students aged 9-11 years old (grades 4-6) with an interest in design, technology, art, science, and engineering. These week-long programs will introduce participants to the fundamentals of art and design with a series of exercises culminating in a final take-home project.

The theme for this summer’s Bits & Bytes program is Drones in the City. We will explore the potential of this disruptive technology and how the city design might respond. Participants will design a city collectively, and will build their own drones. These two week-long programs give students an opportunity to engage with the latest digital technologies, and to develop their design skills in a post-secondary environment.

calEvent.description: This exhibit explores the personalities on both sides of the 1837 conflict through images, stories and the most personal of the Rebellion artifacts - Prisoners' Boxes carved by jailed rebels awaiting their fate. William Lyon Mackenzie led the Rebellion so there’s no better place to explore and learn about early Canadian – and Toronto – history. Mackenzie House is one of 10 Toronto History Museums which explore where Toronto's many pasts, presents and futures meet. It interprets urban Victorian life of the 1860s and the evolution of democratic institutions through the lens of Toronto's first Mayor William Lyon Mackenzie.

calEvent.description:
Imaginary Nonsense:
A Kaleidoscopic Journey of Abstraction Through Painting is a solo exhibition by Nicolas Pearson:

"My work is primarily abstract oil and acrylic paintings. I produce my work in a subconscious manner -I start with an idea and jump into the painting, changing my vision as inspiration hits me, from my fascination for the natural world and random mundane items I encounter in my day to day life. Anything can be a visual stimulate and can be incorporated in my art, the idea that anything and everything can become art gives me motivation."

calEvent.description:
Looking for a beautiful space to enjoy your lunch break outdoors this summer? Mackenzie House is hosting a monthly live music concert as part of the Downtown Yonge BIA's Play the Parks initiative. Tables and chairs will be set up in the museum's courtyard where different musical groups will play each month. 

Mackenzie House is one of 10 Toronto History Museums which explore where Toronto's many pasts, presents and futures meet. It interprets urban Victorian life of the 1860s and the evolution of democratic institutions through the lens of Toronto's first Mayor William Lyon Mackenzie.

calEvent.description:
Throughout 'The Life of a Dead Tree', insects will be collected as they emerge out of the ash tree on display. This workshop begins with an introduction on what invasive species are, how they enter our ecosystems, and the risks they present.

Participants will then have the opportunity to look at insect specimens and identify whether they are invasive or not. Those interested will also have the option to stay and draw an insect or write what about they learned in the workshop.

Children under 12 must be accompanied by a caregiver.
calEvent.otherCostInfo: Includes museum admission
calEvent.shortDescription: This workshop begins with an introduction on what invasive species are, how they enter our ecosystems, and the risks they present. Participants will then have the opportunity to look at insect specimens and identify whether they are invasive or not.
calEvent.eventName: Invasive or not? - With in-museum scientist Alexandra Ntoukas

locations.address: 158 Sterling Rd, Toronto, ON M6R 2B2, Canada

calEvent.description:
Decomposers, such as molds, fungi and mushrooms, are part of the final stages in the decline of a tree. They break down wood and create opportunities for insect life.

Join our in-museum scientist, Alexandra Ntoukas, for a workshop that focuses on the different types of decomposers and their unique characteristics and functions.

Using magnifying glasses, participants will learn how to identify molds and the important role decomposers play in our ecosystems.

Children under 12 must be accompanied by a caregiver.
calEvent.otherCostInfo: Includes museum admission
calEvent.shortDescription: Join in-museum scientist, Alexandra Ntoukas, for a workshop that focuses on the different types of decomposers and their unique characteristics and functions!

The latest show of the season features Moodset, a jazz and R&B collective, whose five members are all either enrolled or alumni of U of T's jazz performance program. They aim to create a vibrant atmosphere, with an emphasis on the creation of original music and soulful sounds.

City Hall Live provides local artists the opportunity to show off their contribution to the diverse and varied wealth of music that makes up Toronto. You can find more of Moodset's work at: https://www.moodsetmusic.com/

calEvent.description: Join the Toronto Mendelssohn Choir for a special 125th anniversary gala concert in the acoustic and architectural splendour of Koerner Hall. The TMC, under conductor David Fallis, will be joined by the Toronto Symphony Orchestra for a program that spans the three centuries in which the TMC has been singing - Gabriel Fauré's Requiem (re-orchestrated in 1894, the founding year of the TMC); Igor Stravinsky's Symphony of Psalms (1930); and a new commission by acclaimed Cree composer Andrew Balfour. Join the choir and patrons for cake after the concert.
calEvent.otherCostInfo: $20 VoxTix available for patrons 30 and under.

- Take home free food!

calEvent.description:
Come on a twilight walk and hear some little-known stories of High Park.  The cool breeze, the leafy shade of the trees and the setting sun will provide the perfect backdrop.

Learn about natural features of the park and how they've changed over thousands of years, stop by Grenadier Pond to share theories about the origins of its name, and have an eerie interlude at the Howard Tomb near the south end of the park.

We'll conclude with some behind-the-scenes ghost stories and a Victorian fruit drink inside Colborne Lodge.

This event is part of Toronto History Museums' RAW History Thursdays programming.This event is part of Toronto History Museums' RAW History Thursdays programming.
calEvent.otherCostInfo: Plus tax

calEvent.description:
Photomagic 44 is a five-day photography camp for youth aged 13 -19. This innovative and intensive week-long camp utilizes the extensive production and darkroom facilities at Gallery 44.

Gallery 44 is situated among many of Toronto’s leading artist-run galleries. During the week, students will learn the art of analog photography, how to process their film and print their image in a black and white darkroom. This is the only analog photography workshop that is entirely hands-on in Toronto!

After the summer camp, students will be invited to exhibit their work in a professional artist-run gallery!

calEvent.description: Humber by Canoe is a full day of free, family activities including paddling, live entertainment, heritage walks and celebratory activities for the Humber River's 20th Anniversary as a designated Canadian Heritage River. The event offers free paddling opportunities and safety demonstrations allowing participants to get on the river and explore the natural heritage for them selves. Humber by Canoe is the perfect way to experience the rich heritage that spurred the designation of the Humber River in the midst of the City of Toronto, and to help celebrate, protect, and restore the River for generations to come.

calEvent.description:
29Rooms is an immersive, pop-up event to Toronto for the first time, as part of a five-city tour.

Expand Your Reality experience will create new, bold and thought-provoking moments that bring Refinery29’s mission and multi-sensory spaces to life in collaboration with global artists, creators, visionaries, meaningful causes, and brands. Each room will put visitors at the center of the event with hands-on activities and several phone-free experiences, sparking engagement and igniting self-expression, storytelling and dialogue.

29Rooms will also feature city-specific collaborations with local artists from Chicago, Dallas, Atlanta, Toronto and Washington D.C. Additionally, some audience favorite rooms including: Teenage Bedroom, a technicolor fur bedroom that transports you back to the 90s teenage years and Inner Beauty Ball, a dance party where guests are invited to express, celebrate and dance will be included in the experience.
calEvent.otherCostInfo:
Early-bird ticket pricing available in limited quantities starting May 22.

calEvent.description:
Join us for a collective reading and discussion of anonymous transcripts of oral history research around cruising encounters in Queen’s Park.

Inspired by the ‘cruising’ histories of nearby Queen’s Park, Intimate Encounters ~ Animate Histories considers the diverse ways in which culturally-specific experiences of desire, physical expression, and social connection take up space across Toronto, and how this is complicated by an increasingly gentrified urban landscape. 

Led by artist Abdi Osman and curator Ellyn Walker, this project makes visible the dignity, love, and generative practices embedded in local Black, Trans, and Queer histories through community art-making workshops, programs, and a cumulative exhibition.

calEvent.description:
Fire is familiar to all cultures and peoples but often missing in urban environments. A campfire by design takes the form of a circle – everyone is equal, everyone can contribute, everyone can see each other. Fire acts as a distinct teaching tool: it is a living thing – like us – that needs to be fed, sustained, and looked after or it will die, but – like us – must not rage out of control. 

Shadowland’s Campfire Project is open to everyone of all ages, and offers the experience of fire through storytelling, music, Indigenous teachings, community gathering – and even marshmallow roasting.

calEvent.description:
From Dracula and Frankenstein to the fear of being buried alive and the fetish of post mortem photos, take this interactive tour that explores the Victorian obsession with death.

Compare the themes, threats and symbols in Victorian horror literature and the emergence of the Penny Dreadfuls! Explore Victorian funeral traditions including rarely seen artifacts from the City of Toronto collection. Discover the tradition of post mortem and "ghost" photos.

Mackenzie House is one of 10 Toronto History Museums which explore where Toronto's many pasts, presents and futures meet. It interprets urban Victorian life of the 1860s and the evolution of democratic institutions through the lens of Toronto's first Mayor William Lyon Mackenzie.

Please call 416-392-6915 for specific accessibility questions.

This event is part of Toronto History Museums' RAW History Thursdays programming.

calEvent.description:
Join artist and scholar Bettina Forget for a talk bridging art, space science, and the timely topic of women’s representation.

Of the 1,605 named craters on the moon, only 29 are named after women — an issue that Forget has tackled in a series of works called Women With Impact. She’ll discuss the underrepresentation of women in the historical science record through the lens of this piece, which fuses drawing and selenographic research.

Forget will also share insights gleaned from her project Exoplanet Zoo, created while she served as artist-in-residence at the Mont-Mégantic Observatory. Using 3D printers Forget produced exoplanet sculptures that she displays in a “Cabinet of Curiosities,” evoking Victorian-era science.
calEvent.otherCostInfo: Includes museum admission

calEvent.description:
Come by for a free outdoor screening of First Man in celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 moon landing. 

Directed by award-winning filmmaker Damien Chazelle, First Man tells the riveting story of NASA's goal to land a man on the moon. Starring Ryan Gosling and Claire Foy, the film is a look at the life of Neil Armstrong and the mission that led him to become the first man to walk on the moon.  

In addition to the screening of the acclaimed feature film, guests are welcome to grab free popcorn at the snack bar!
